title-group.article-title: Association Between Coronary Collaterals and Serum Uric Acid Level in Chinese Population With Acute Coronary Syndrome

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Internal Medicine, Division of Cardiology, Kaohsiung Medical University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan
2Graduate Institute of Medicine, Kaohsiung Medical University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan
3Faculty of Medicine, Kaohsiung Medical University, Kaohsiung, Taiwan
4Department of Internal Medicine, Kaohsiung Municipal Hsiao-Kang Hospital, Kaohsiung, Taiwan

author-notes.corresp: Tsung-Hsien Lin, Department of Internal Medicine, Division of Cardiology, Kaohsiung Medical University Hospital, 100 Tzyou 1st Road, Kaohsiung. 80708, Taiwan. Email: lth@kmu.edu.tw

body.p: We read the article by Duran et al, which evaluated the association between coronary collateral formation and serum uric acid (SUA) level in patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS). 1 Duran et al reported that both the presence of coronary collateral vessels (CCV) and the development of good CCV were significantly associated with low levels of SUA and suggested that high levels of SUA affect CCV development negatively in patients with ACS. 1 In addition, Kasapkara et al also reported that elevated SUA level on admission is associated with poor CCV development and may be a useful biomarker for stratification of risk in patients with non-ST elevation ACS. 2 Therefore, we reviewed our coronary angiographic data in Kaohsiung Medical University Hospital (KMUH) to see whether there is a similar result in the Chinese population.

We evaluated 324 consecutive patients with ACS having significant coronary artery disease (sCAD). On the first day of admission to the hospital, blood samples were taken and the SUA levels were analyzed. Coronary angiography was performed for patients during index admission. Significant coronary artery disease was defined as coronary diameter stenosis >70%. The Rentrop collateral scoring system was used to classify patients into poor (Rentrop grades 0 and 1) or good (Rentrop grades 2 and 3) collateral group. 3 In addition, Rentrop grade 0 was accepted as absence of CCV and Rentrop grade ≥1 was accepted as presence of CCV. Our study population included 324 participants (252 male; 72 female; average age, 62.7 ± 13.4 years). Among them, 84 patients (25.9%) had 1-vessel disease, 103 patients (31.8%) had 2-vessel disease, and 137 patients (42.3%) had 3-vessel disease. We found 150 (46.3%) patients had no coronary collaterals. In patients with collaterals, the Rentrop grade was distributed as follows: 62 (19.1%) with grade 1, 81 (25.0%) with grade 2, and 31 (9.6%) with grade 3. Baseline characteristics in patients with ACS having poor and good CCV are shown in Table 1. The patients with poor CCV had fewer diseased vessels (2.02 ± 0.82 vs 2.44 ± 0.72, P < .001). There was no significant difference in other variables including SUA level between the 2 groups. In addition, baseline characteristics in patients with ACS having and those without CCV are shown in Table 2. The patients without CCV had fewer diseased vessels (2.00 ± 0.84 vs 2.30 ± 0.76, P = .001). There was also no significant difference in other variables including SUA level between the 2 groups.

caption.p: Baseline Characteristics in Patients With Acute Coronary Syndrome Having Poor and Good Collaterals.

fn.p: Abbreviations: BMI, body mass index; DM, diabetes; HTN, hypertension; eGFR, estimated glomerular filtration rate.

caption.p: Baseline Characteristics in Patients With Acute Coronary Syndrome Having Collaterals and Those Without Collaterals.

fn.p: Abbreviations: BMI, body mass index; DM, diabetes; HTN, hypertension; eGFR, estimated glomerular filtration rate.

body.p: In our study, SUA level did not have significant association with the presence and development of CCV in a Chinese population. These findings are not the same as studies of Duran et al and Kasapkara et al. 1–2 Therefore, it seems that the influence of SUA for CCV development might not be similar between different races. However, the detailed mechanism still needs to be further investigated.
